sections.section: This tutorial demonstrates how to use a Workload Management Policy to control the maximum throughput of a message flow. This use of a Workload Management Policy is particularly useful when backend systems that a message flow interacts with are unable to keep up with a workload sent from a requesting application.
This tutorial provides a message flow that performs a simple transformation of an XML input message received over HTTP before sending a reply to the requesting application.

If you are using Developer Edition, which restricts message processing to 1 message per second, or your system is unable to process messages through the flow at a rate that exceeds 1 message per second then you will not be able to observe the effects of attaching a Workload Management Policy that is demonstated by this tutorial.

sections.section: Click Import to add the required projects to your workspace:

details.name: The application named WorkloadManagementApplication contains the following resources.
details.details: The application named WorkloadManagementApplication contains the following resources.
A message flow named WorkloadManagementFlow that receives an HTTP message, performs a simple transformation and then sends an HTTP reply.
An XML input message named TestMessage.xml to test the message flow with.

A BAR File named wlm.bar which contains WorkloadManagementApplication, which itself contains WorkloadManagementFlow. The message flow has been configured to refer to the Workload Management policy (which is described below).

The policy project named MyPolicies contains a Workload Management Policy named WLM_MaxRate_Policy. To start with this policy defines a Maximum Rate (messages per second) of 100,000. Later in the tutorial we will show the impact of changing this threshold.
The two java projects named PerfHarness and HTTPPerfHarness jointly provide a testing capability which we will use to drive workload through the message flow.

sections.section: Deploy the Application, Message Flow and Workload Management Policy

This tutorial assumes you have an Integration node owned integration server, or a stand-alone integration server already created. Other tutorials in the tutorial gallery will help you with this if you're not sure what this means.

To deploy the artifacts locate the provided BAR file named wlm.bar inside the application project named WorkloadManagementApplication, and drag and drop it on to your integration server in the Integration Explorer view (by default shown in the bottom left corner of your Toolkit).

overview.name: Run
overview.heading: Test the scenario
overview._runComment: The full steps for the user to run through the tutorial. Use 'sections' to render paragraphs, 'steps' with a type of 'ordered' or 'unordered' to render HTML lists, and 'substeps' to render nested lists.

sections.section: To test the scenario, you will generate a workload of messages for the message flow which runs for one minute. The message processing rate will be reported. Next, you will update the Workload Management Policy and redeploy it before repeating the one minute test, which will demonstrate the message processing rate being limited.

The PerfHarness Test Tool is a small java utility written by IBM and freely available to help you generate a workload of HTTP request messages that are processed by the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow. The link below provides more details about the PerfHarness tool, but for simplicity the tool is already available for you to run from your Toolkit workspace using the projects you imported earlier in this tutorial:

details.details: Check the properties of your integration server to determine which port is being used by the HTTP Input node in the deployed message flow. By default this is likely to be port 7800.

Expand the src folder of the PerfHarness project, right-click JMSPerfHarness.java and choose the menu option Run As > Run Configurations. From the list, select Java Application and click the New button to create a new run configuration.
On the Main tab, check that Project = PerfHarness and Main class = JMSPerfHarness

On the Arguments tab, copy and paste the following into the Program arguments text window: -tc http.HTTPRequestor -rl 60 -jh localhost -jp {HTTPPort} -mf {WorkspacePath}/WorkloadManagementApplication/TestMessages/TestMessage.xml -wi 10 -to 10000 -sh false -ws 1 -dn 1 -sc BasicStats -ss 5 -nt 1 -ur wlm
where:
{HTTPPort} is the port the Integration Server is listening on for HTTP requests from the previous step
{WorkspacePath} is the location of your current Toolkit workspace.
On the Classpath tab, select User Entries, click Add Projects, and select the HTTPPerfHarness and PerfHarness projects

When you click Run, the PerfHarness will run for 60 seconds and every 5 seconds output the message rate at which it is processing messages. The actual message rate achieved will be dependent upon the performance of your system but it needs to be in excess of 1 message per second for you to observe the effects of applying the Workload Management Policy in this tutorial.

sections.section: Redeploy the Workload Management Policy with a lower rate to restrict the message throughput
Use the WLM_MaxRate_Policy Workload Management Policy to restrict the throughput of the WorkloadManagementFlow message flow by completing the following steps:

details.details: Look inside the MyPolicies project, open WLM_MaxRate_Policy and change the Maximum Rate (Messages per second) parameter from its current value of 100000 to the value 1.
Deploy the update by dragging and dropping the MyPolicies project on to the integration server.

sections.section: Re-run the workload with the new Workload Management Policy in place
Now the Workload Management Policy has been updated, repeat the same test as before and observe that the message processing rate has now been limited to 1 message per second.
